body: I just patched this into google, and verified that it fixed the linkage error that the internal team was seeing

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

```
[microbenchmarks] No significant performance differences
```
Worth noting; I think putting this query into channel_info makes sense. I am currently implementing the subchannel_refs part, and that will also be an added field to channel_info

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

```
[microbenchmarks] No significant performance differences
```

Ok, I restarted and approached this from a different way.

See description for details.

As far as results, this fixes the internal issue. Also, it only produces connectivity data when the ChannelNode is a type that actually has that concept.

```
$ bins/opt/h2_full_test channelz
{"ref":{"channelId":"1"},"data":{"state":{"state":"READY"},"target":"localhost:21561","callsStarted":"2","callsSucceeded":"1","callsFailed":"1","lastCallStartedTimestamp":"2018-06-28T18:08:45.509934369Z"}}
```

Then for a direct channel:
```
$ bins/opt/h2_fd_test channelz
{"ref":{"channelId":"1"},"data":{"target":"fixture_client","callsStarted":"2","callsSucceeded":"1","callsFailed":"1","lastCallStartedTimestamp":"2018-06-28T18:09:16.706423013Z"}}
```

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```

cc @nicolasnoble, this fixes the build error we spoke about yesterday

As I worker on the next parts, I realized it made more sense to pass the json down to the subclasses, and then handle the population there.

The code to support subchannel population will also follow this pattern. It's a little nicer because it lets the client_channel ChannelNode dig directly into client_channel API without and linker errors

```
[trickle] No significant performance differences
```
